newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil September exports drop 1.25 pct vs year ago.
newsitem.headline: Brazil September exports drop 1.25 pct vs year ago.

text.p: Brazil exported $4.115 billion of goods in September, down 1.25 percent from September 1995, the Ministry of Industry and Commerce said Friday.
The ministry said in a statement that average daily exports reached $196 million, down 5.9 percent from the daily average of $208.4 million in the same month a year ago.
Exports in the January-September period of 1996 rose to $35.858 billion from $34.178 billion in the same period a year ago, the ministry said.
It said that exports of primary goods increased 13.57 percent in September compared with the same month of 1995, "pushed by the high external price of soymeal."
Semi-manufactured exports fell 3.49 percent year-on-year, and manufactured goods dropped 6.46 percent.

An exemption on the so-called ICMS sales and circulation tax on exports, which went into effect September 16, produced "a relatively better" performance of daily averages in the second half of the month, the ministry said.
"It is to be expected in the medium and long term that there will be a significant increase in competitiveness," it said.
The biggest gains from the ICMS exemption were likely in exports of soybeans, coffee, aluminium, tobacco, beef, sugar, metals, minerals, cocoa and orange juice.
